newsitem.title: INDIA: Mother Teresa takes first steps since surgery.
newsitem.headline: Mother Teresa takes first steps since surgery.

text.p: Mother Teresa took her first steps on Wednesday since life-saving surgery last week, and said she was strong and wanted to go home.
Aided by medical staff, Mother Teresa, 86, walked for the first time since her heart operation, said Dr Tarun Praharaj, a member of the panel treating the Roman Catholic nun.
"She walked with support. Just a few steps," he told reporters in Calcutta.
The missionary was impatient to leave Calcutta's B.M. Birla Heart Research Centre and continue her work, the doctor said.
"I'm quite strong. I want to go home," Praharaj quoted Mother Teresa as saying.
Praharaj said doctors hoped to let her go home in a few days. "We will try to release her at the weekend. Maybe three, four days from now. But it all depends on her progress."
The 1979 Nobel Peace Prize winner had surgery last week to clear two blocked arteries and had appeared to be recovering when longstanding kidney and lung problems resurfaced.
Mother Teresa, revered for her life-long devotion to the destitute and dying, has been suffering from an irregular heartbeat, bronchial pneumonia and weak kidneys.
Praharaj said the nun's kidney functions had improved.
"On a scale of one to 10, I would rate her three," Praharaj said when asked how much Mother Teresa had improved since the surgery.

He said the doctors were keeping their fingers crossed that Mother Teresa would continue to gain strength. "Doctors are encouraged and optimistic. However, Mother is not out of danger yet," a regular medical bulletin said, citing her continued irregular heart beat.

Praharaj said Mother Teresa was well enough up to sit in a chair for brief periods. She met sisters from her Missionaries of Charity order in the morning, and listened to mass. On Tuesday, doctors said her recovery would be a slow process and she might never be as active as before.
Despite a series of health problems, Mother Teresa had kept up a seemingly tireless pace in her Order and travelled widely before her latest illness. Her order runs 456 homes in 111 countries.
The nun, who was fitted with a heart pacemaker in 1989, had her first heart operation in the United States in 1991 and her second at the Birla centre in 1993.
Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda planned to make a special trip to Calcutta on Thursday to visit Mother Teresa in the clinic, his office said.
